poem:
Doctors for the Earth  

In white coats,  
they stand, a line  
that sings of Hippocrates—  
and green, the veins  
beneath our feet,  
pulsing through the grime.  

Their hands, unbound—  
a stethoscope,  
a plea against  
the fevered sky.  

Let them heal—  
let them heal  
where all life  
begins.

Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
